The "infinite to-do list vs. finite human capacity" thing is exactly what I see break people. I've been interviewing people about their actual to-do lists and systems, and the ones drowning in overwhelm always have these massive master lists that just keep growing. They're adding faster than they're completing, and the list becomes this guilt monument that follows them around. Your "daily adventure" reframe is smart - it's basically forcing the prioritization conversation that most people avoid. I talked to someone recently who had 127 items on their to-do list and when I asked "if you could only do THREE this week, which three?" they genuinely couldn't answer. The list had become a place to hide from decision-making instead of a tool for clarity. The "might-do" vs "have-to-do" distinction is real too - most people's urgency is imaginary.

@aliabdaal All of it is related to a certain bias that exists in all societies in every corner of the world, which exists because people ascribe a higher standard to certain career paths (and expect their kids &/or relatives to follow the path). 

Naturally, when they see their kid/relative/friend do something entirely different to which they either ascribe ridicule or indifference, they are then bound to make a negative comment. So, it speaks to their own bias rather than your own decision and career path. The one thing you need to be firm on is to follow your own aspirations and dreams AND, most importantly be strong if that path doesn’t work out for you knowing that you gave it your best shot. If you do not succeed, never let those same people ridicule you further (they are, once again, bound to make some comment because of their own bias). Be proud that you tried your best. 

I started my channel with these thoughts in mind and although I am struggling, I am learning something new with each video and while I might never get monetized or grow, there are lessons I am learning which I can apply to other ventures in the future. 

Stay focused & positive, ignore the noise and march on, my friends!

I think the idea of winning "life changing" money on a lottery hits different than just not having financial worries. Ask yourself "what would I do if money was not a consideration?" (i.e. you won a prize whereby you would get the equivalent of a decent salary every month for the rest of your life, but it would not be millions in one go). I could not answer this question for years, and beat myself up because I thought I was unimaginative/boring! It's not about being positive or manifesting it's just a raw look at the financial engineering that the most powerful people use. It explains why my 401k is a good tool for them and not necessarily for me. It's a technical manual disguised as a revolutionary idea. I found it on Lunqet Books and it changed how I look at my job.

I used to be totally stuck hating my 9 to 5 because I didn't see an escape. Seriously, The Elite's Wealth Secrets by Robert Bluestein changed everything I thought I knew about money. It’s a real blueprint for how to stop chasing income and start building assets that actually work for you. The results came so fast that I was able to quit my job in two months.

What your friend did was brilliant. He didn't ask, "What product can I create?" He asked, "What pain can I cure?" In this first episode of "Freedom Fridays," Ali Abdaal dives into the often-overlooked realm of financial and time freedom, sharing his personal journey and the insights he's gained along the way. 9:30 Actually, this is called the inner critic. It's a perfectly normal experience for most people. 

The keyword being most. And no, being enlightened has nothing to do with the absence of little voice in your head, either. That's called anendophasia; ask me how I know!

Jokes aside, I genuinely have this condition. No little voices in my head. It's astonishingly quiet, and I was very surprised to find out that this wasn't just a figure of speech. Sort of related, my wife actually has aphantasia, which means she can't imagine things / doesn't have a mind's eye. There's also one for being unable to imagine smells, and probably even more.


Oh, and for curious parties, I can imagine sound if I put conscious effort into it (sort of like speaking but inside my head), and I can still imagine songs etc. A complete absence of any inner ear is called anaduralia, which is sort of like a more extreme version of anendophasia. My thoughts are completely wordless, however. It's sort of a flow of ideas and images. I would simply describe it as thinking in thoughts, as weird as that is.

Owning a lot of material things can also
 I.e. property, expensive cars, yachts…can also take away your freedom. You have to maintain them, take insurances…and if you hire staff to take care of them, you still have to take care of your staff. Those are all complexities some people once they get rich, acquire without realizing that it robs them time and freedom.

Time Freedom and Financial Freedom Are Interlocked—but Not Equal.

1. Time Freedom Without Money = Illusion
If you're broke, you're not free. Your time belongs to the job, the bills, the obligations. You’re trading hours for survival, not choice. People romanticize quitting the 9-to-5, but if you have no income stream, all you’ve got is stress disguised as freedom.

2. Financial Freedom Without Time = Golden Cage
You’ve got the cash, but if your schedule is maxed out—meetings, obligations, stress—you’re still a slave. Just richer. Time freedom means autonomy—waking up and choosing what to do, not reacting to what you “have to” do.

You need financial leverage to unlock time freedom. That doesn’t always mean millions—it could be:

1. A business that runs without you.
2. Investments that pay your bills.
3. Skills that let you freelance on your terms.

And from there, time freedom becomes a test of discipline. Most people waste it. They don’t use it to build, they use it to numb.

Don’t get me wrong — what you said was incredibly impactful.
But here’s the thing… I’m a business owner, and I’ve known for years that I need to start a YouTube channel. The problem is, I’m extremely introverted, so I kept putting it off for as long as I can remember.
By the way, I was one of your early students in YouTube Part-Time.
But when I heard you say that I could just do YouTube for fun… wow. I never thought about it that way before. It felt like the pressure of “doing it for my business” suddenly lifted off my shoulders.
It sounds weird, I know. I’m an introvert who doesn’t even want to be on camera — even though I run a business. But now, if I think of doing YouTube just for fun, it suddenly feels possible.
It’s like… I can do it, but I don’t have to do it.
And that small shift changed everything for me.
Anyway, thank you so much, Ali. I’ll update you 12 months from now on how my channel is doing.

Law of serotonin - walk headphone free in nature every day
Most important thing is spending time in natural environments. 
The more you spend in a natural environment, the more you will thrive in productivity/etc.
Getting sunlight exposure in the morning increases cortisol (more awake), synchronizes circadian rhythm, sunlight signal tells our brain to make serotonin so we feel happier and energized throughout the day. Even if it's cloudy, you still get the benefit. On a really sunny day, you need 5 mins, on cloudy day, 15 min.
We make 90% of our serotonin in our gut
Eat foods with lots of fiber. Healthier diet = better feel overall.
Better diet = happy gut = happy brain
When eating stuff, make sure you recognize all ingredients. When eating processed food, your gut has to spend energy removing the toxic stuff rather than creating serotonin.
The healthier the diet, the less depressed you are (probably, not scientifically proven or anything)
If the body is breathing very slowly, serotonin levels rise. 
Resonance breathing - breathe 6 times per minute. 
4 seconds in and 6 seconds out 10 times.
Delta sleep. Have a healthy calming wind down period before sleep. Read and resonance breathe before sleep.

6 years ago  I got into shape and started extreme sports and that really slowed down time compared to the decades of sedentary life  before that, but what has really slowed down time in the last couple of years for me has been travelling overseas for 3 months, every 3 months! I don't have the time to get set in my ways or fall into a mindless routine. Also I am learning a new language which might be partially contributing to this. When overseas in public I am always nervous to talk using my new language skills (or lack thereof!) so that part is true.

Now it's August and I can't believe this Christmas, that still is far away, is the one I will stay in country to visit my parents. Even though I am there every 2 years, it seems like years has gone by since last Christmas, thus I get confused, "is this the one we go visit the parents?". 
It's quite an amazingly large change in perception of time! I'm old so this sudden time shift makes me so happy as all I have heard from older people is time speeds up faster and faster, then you die!

I realised this last year during my gap year. I was straight out of highschool, and the first few months I spent waking up super late, playing games the whole day, doom scrolling all the time, and working part time for aorund 12 hours a week. It became incredibly deppressing, and it felt like the first 4 months of the year had passed by quicker than any other time in my life. I realised that I needed to actually experience new and healthy things if I wanted my life to feel slower and have more substance, so I made changes, did new things, played less games, started going to the gym and focused on improving my drawing skills. It worked. the second part of my gap year felt like it went by so much slower, and like I was actually doing good things

Read indistractable and Digital Minimalism

Also screens are not the issue, but what’s on them. Yeah ok too much screen time does put too much strain on your eyes and lead to headaches etc, but the things we blame on screens is actually due to what sort of stuff we are consuming, namely a lot of mindless, short content, playing havoc with our attention. If someone spent 18 hours of a day reading a book on their iPad, their eyes would probably feel the strain and we’d probably recommend they read on paper or e-ink, but they may not feel like they’ve wasted their day, depending on the book/other commitments they’re neglecting. So we need to build systems that help us detach from various fast paced streams of information, such as social media or the news

6 hours and 40 minutes? I don’t buy that. Ok yeah let’s not include watching TV on an actual TV let’s say. I’d say a significant majority of people are looking at a desktop or laptop or tablet screen for much of the working day (let’s say 6-8 hours). That’s 6 hours 40 minutes even before using screens outside work is taken into account. Most people use YouTube, Instagram and Tiktok, each I’d say for close to an hour. So we’re up to about 9-11 hours. Plus then texting and other web browsing and I’d reckon we’re looking at more like 11-13 hours. People are on screens during every hour they’re not asleep. Most people sleep about 6-8 hours. So for 16-18 hours of the day people are looking at screens in those hours. By these very rough calculations there are 5 hours without screens. That’s about 80% of the whole day spent on screens. I just don’t know where these stats come from. Anyone else think they’re massively undercooked?

Notes:
- People are experiencing more anxiety and depression due to the endless levels of dopamine that we get
- Things that don't release a lot of dopamine (reading, watching a slow documentary, taking a walk in the park, being with friends) don't make us feel good anymore
- Dopamine detox: Stop doing too much of what gives you the bad dopamine (scrolling, tv, video games, gambling, sugary foods). Learn to enjoy the simple pleasures in life.

There is a BBC podcast called “All In The Mind” where a researcher that studied exactly this topic said that it had to be balanced. When they tried to replicate the study on the long run, they found that the people that benefited from it also tended to stick to it, because indeed they found benefits, while people that didn’t find much difference tended to stop and leave the study. It had a tendency to push the experiment to a biased positivity. So it might be more of a “try, you have nothing to lose, but if it doesn’t work for you, don’t sweat it “.
